newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Midwest hogs called steady-lower Monday-trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Midwest hogs called steady-lower Monday-trade.

text.p: Hog prices were called steady to $1.00 per cwt lower in Monday's Midwest cash markets as livestock dealers expect markets to return to normal after two days of steep gains.
"I think we will get back to reality and be $0.50 to $1.00 lower," said an Indiana dealer, who said recent price increases appeared overdone.

Snow and cold across the Midwest the past two days reduced hog marketings and forced meat packers to bid higher for the limited supplies. USDA reported actual Thursday marketings were 100,000 head, down 5,000 from its estimate.
Hog prices, basis interior Iowa-southern Minnesota, traded up to $55.00 Friday versus $51.50 on Wednesday, USDA said.

Weather was the one variable that could keep hog prices moving higher, cash dealers said. Frigid cold was forecast for the Midwest this weekend, but meteorologists said temperatures should moderate by Monday.
